messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 61 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Multilevel regression with poststratification for the national level Viber/Street poll on the 2020 presidential election in Belarus

Paper Abstract: Abstract Independent sociological polls are forbidden in Belarus. Online polls performed without sound scientific rigour do not yield representative results. Yet, both inside and outside Belarus it is of great importance to obtain precise estimates of the ratings of all candidates. These ratings could function as reliable proxies for the election’s outcomes. We conduct an independent poll based on the combination of the data collected via Viber and on the streets of Belarus. The Viber and the street data samples consist of almost 45 000 and 1 150 unique observations respectively. Bayesian regressions with poststratification were build to estimate ratings of the candidates and rates of early voting turnout for the population as a whole and within various focus subgroups. We show that both the officially announced results of the election and early voting rates are highly improbable. With a probability of at least 95%, Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya’s rating lies between 75% and 80%, whereas Aliaksandr Lukashenka’s rating lies between 13% and 18% and early voting rate predicted by the method ranges from 9% to 13% of those who took part in the election. These results contradict the officially announced outcomes, which are 10.12%, 80.11%, and 49.54% respectively and lie far outside even the 99.9% credible intervals predicted by our model. The only marginal groups of people where the upper bounds of the 99.9% credible intervals of the rating of Lukashenka are above 50% are people older than 60 and uneducated people. For all other marginal subgroups, including rural residents, even the upper bounds of 99.9% credible intervals for Lukashenka are far below 50%. The same is true for the population as a whole. Thus, with a probability of at least 99.9% Lukashenka could not have had enough electoral support to win the 2020 presidential election in Belarus.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 61 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 61"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Media in Belarus 2020. Market, laws and information security",
        "The election in Belarus. Internal troops in the center of Minsk and long queues at the election areas",
        "Education level of population",
        "Age and sex structure of the average annual population size in the Republic of Belarus for 2019",
        "Central Election Committee: due to epidemic situation, the number of observers at polling stations will be reduced",
        "Observation of the early parliamentary elections in Belarus",
        "How does multilevel regression and poststratification perform with conventional national surveys?",
        "Independent Exit Poll Data: Tsikhanouskaya - 71,1%, Lukashenka - 15,7%",
        "Bayesian inference in political science, finance, and marketing research",
        "Improving and validating survey estimates of religious demography using Bayesian multilevel models and poststratification",
        "Belarus’s Lukashenko jailed election rivals and mocked women as unfit to lead. Now one is leading the opposition",
        "Multilevel regression and poststratification: A modeling approach to estimating population quantities from highly selected survey samples",
        "CEC of Belarus approves the results of the presidential election",
        "Improving multilevel regression and poststratification with structured priors",
        "Mister P: What’s its secret sauce?",
        "Using Multilevel Regression and Poststratification to Estimate Dynamic Public Opinion",
        "We have counted votes in Belarus according to the protocols of 1 million voters",
        "I found a very elegant way to show the scale of the stuffing for Lukashenka",
        "President of Belarus Wins Referendum on Expanding His Power",
        "Belarusian Electoral Law",
        "0.009% of Opposition. A Description of Parties and Organizations Counting the Ballots",
        "An introduction to multilevel regression and post-stratification for estimating constituency opinion",
        "Exploring constituency-level estimates for the 2017 British general election",
        "Predicting state presidential election results using national tracking polls and multilevel regression with poststratification (MRP)",
        "How should we estimate public opinion in the states?",
        "Bayesian spatial modelling with r-inla",
        "polca: An r package for polytomous variable latent class analysis",
        "Using multilevel regression with poststratification to obtain regional health estimates from a Facebook-recruited sample",
        "Bayesian hierarchical spatial models: Implementing the Besag York Mollié model in stan",
        "Boss of Belarus Seems to Win Referendum, as Expected",
        "Elections in Belarus",
        "Bayesian multilevel estimation with poststratification: State-level estimates from national polls",
        "An intuitive Bayesian spatial model for disease mapping that accounts for scaling",
        "Belarus crowdfunds to fight coronavirus as leader denies it exists",
        "Approximate Bayesian inference for latent Gaussian models by using integrated nested Laplace approximations",
        "Evaluation of early voting turnout in Belarus based on official protocols and reports from the observers",
        "Referendum 1996. What changed 19 years ago?",
        "Multilevel structured (regression) and post-stratification",
        "Smallpdf.com - A Free Solution to all your PDF Problems",
        "People won’t swallow Lukashenka’s painted victory",
        "On the shelves. Voter Memo: All About Voting in Ten Answers",
        "Whom did you vote for at the presidential elections in the Republic of Belarus",
        "Belarus’s election was a sham. The West’s response has been feeble",
        "Final Report on 2020 Presidential Elections in Belarus",
        "Accurate approximations for posterior moments and marginal densities",
        "Voting patterns in 2016: Exploration using multilevel regression and poststratification (MRP) on pre-election polls",
        "The most popular messenger in Belarus named",
        "Viber REST API",
        "Viber Admin Panel",
        "Forecasting elections with non-representative polls",
        "How should we measure district-level public opinion on individual issues?",
        "Romanization of Belarusian",
        "Multilevel regression with poststratification",
        "Estimating General Election Support for President Using Multilevel Regression & Poststratification (MRP)",
        "The situation with objective assessments of the voting results in Belarus is bad. Trust in the official results is zero, because the CEC itself did everything to discredit itself",
        "National Poll Analysis",
        "National Poll Project",
        "National Poll: An opportunity to find out the pre-election ratings of presidential candidates in the Republic of Belarus",
        "Multilevel regression and poststratification for small-area estimation of population health outcomes: a case study of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease prevalence using the behavioral risk factor surveillance system",
        "Belarus: Rule of Law Dimensions of 2020 Presidential Elections",
        "A professor from the USA studied data from the protocols of commissions in Belarus and found statistical anomalies"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 61 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Multilevel regression with poststratification for the national level Viber/Street poll on the 2020 presidential election in Belarus, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
